zone.line: to my slavery.X But But shouldcould I shouldleave
Geneva & the fiend beli & my friends
unconscious of the existence of their
enemy & unprotected from his attacks
exasperated as he might be by my depar
ture - But then he had promised to
follow me every where & might
he not accompany me to England - the
thought was dreadful in itself but
soothing inasmuch as my friends would
be in safety. XThe thoughts occurred
rapidly to me & I answered my fa
ther with eagerness that I should
be delighted to visit Engl England
with Clerval and that travel the
idea of traveling was inchanting to
me.
Your journey travels, said my
father, will occupy the space of
two years - on your return you

line.del: shall be united to your cousin

zone.line: Our plan was soon arranged.
I should travel to Strasburgh where
Clerval would join me & we
should proceed down the Rhine
together.tow Some short time would
be spent in the towns of Holland
& many months in England. We were
to return by france & it was sup
posed that this tour woudl occupy
the space of two years. My father
pleased himself with the reflection
that I should be united to Eliza
beth immediately on my return
X
